Comment: *they'll create some excuse to fit...*   The U.S. Constitution's Suspension Clause in Article I, Section 9, states that the writ of habeas corpus "shall not be suspended, unless when in cases of rebellion or invasion the public safety may require it." This means the right to challenge unlawful detention, known as habeas corpus, can only be suspended in times of rebellion or invasion when the public safety is at risk.Â

Comment: > â€œCongress has the authority to suspend habeas corpus - not Stephen Miller, not the president," Marc Elias, an attorney for the Democratic Party, told MSNBC.  This isnâ€™t some fringe legal theory.  This was already settled in 1861 when Lincoln tried to unilaterally suspend habeas corpus. The case of Ex parte Merryman ruled that only Congress has this power as itâ€™s defined in Article 1 Section 9 Clause 2. Congress had to retroactively revoke habeas corpus with the Habeas Corpus Suspension Act of 1863.  He has **zero** legal basis here.

Author: BlackDeath3

Comment: Shit is what it is. I didn't sign up for it, but I'm also the worst possible person to drag into a fight. I don't want to fight, but that means that I don't fight nice or fair once you make me.   The single greatest compliment I've ever been given was from my college buddy's brother who is a Navy SEAL. We were talking about all the shit he may or may not have gotten into and I told him this same philosophy on disagreeing and fighting. And he said that it's accurate... Fighting is almost always dumb and bad, and it should be avoided whenever possible. But once it has to happen, know that it's a fight before the other guy does and commit to going 10x farther than he ever would.
